importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident when Billy Joe Cagle was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, marking a key event in the timeline of the threat and arrest.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time Cagle arrived at the airport terminal, when surveillance footage shows him entering the airport and approaching the TSA checkpoint.

keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, planned to shoot up the world's busiest airport, Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport, as revealed in a social media livestream.
Cagle was arrested at the airport after receiving a tip from his family who alerted law enforcement to his online threat of violence.
Police found an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal.
Cagle was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
The arrest was described as a success due to early intervention by a concerned family, which prevented a potential mass shooting.
Cagle had disclosed mental health struggles, including schizophrenia and medication use, and had previously assured close friends he was safe.
Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which he was legally prohibited from possessing.
The incident highlighted the role of community vigilance and social media in identifying potential threats before they materialize.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, Billy Joe Cagle, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted police that he had streamed on social media a plan to 'shoot it up' at the airport. Authorities found an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who had disclosed mental health issues including schizophrenia, was charged with terroristic threats, attempted aggravated assault, and illegal firearm possession. The incident was averted due to early warning from family members and community vigilance, and the arrest was praised by both local officials and federal leaders as a success. The case underscores the dangers of online threats, the importance of social media monitoring, and the role of community networks in preventing mass violence.
title: Man Arrested at Atlanta Airport After Threatening to Shoot Up Terminal in Social Media Livestream
